West Nile virus involves numerous species of birds, with as many as 300 species known to be infected ( Wonham et al. [2006]). Reservoir competence and disease susceptibility are known to vary widely within birds ( Kilpatrick et al. [2007]). The reservoir for Nipah and Hendra viruses is fruit bats that transmit the viruses to pigs and horses, respectively ( Daniels et al. [2007]). The dog is the major reservoir for rabies throughout the world but wildlife reservoirs for rabies include foxes, coyotes, jackals, skunks, raccoons, insectivorous bats and yellow mongooses ( Hemachudha and Rupprecht [2005]). Depending on reservoir competence, biodiversity effects can be amplified or diluted ( Schmidt and Ostfeld [2001], Dobson [2004], Keesing et al. [ 2006, 2006).
